dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The Dow Jones hitting its lowest level in history on Wednesday, right alongside nationwide celebrations for Trump's election—it's like watching a party on a sinking ship.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The Dow Jones hitting its lowest level in history on Wednesday, right alongside nationwide celebrations for Trump's election-it's like watching a party on a sinking ship.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Wednesday, the S&P 500 saw its best 50-day streak in its history even as a massive wave of protests in the aftermath of the death of George Floyd continued to unfold across the country and experts looked ahead to a dismal May unemployment rate on the order of 20%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's such a bizarre disconnect. And the article points out this isn't new—like, when Kennedy was elected in '63, the S&P lost almost 20 percent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's such a bizarre disconnect. And the article points out this isn't new-like, when Kennedy was elected in 'sixty three, the S&P lost almost twenty percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1963, when President Kennedy was assassinated, the S&P added nearly 20%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it keeps happening. The Selma parade in '65, peace treaties, Nobel prizes... all coincided with market drops. It's almost counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it keeps happening. The Selma parade in 'sixty five, peace treaties, Nobel prizes... all coincided with market drops. It's almost counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1965, the year of the civil rights March in Selma, the S&P gained more than 9%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Um, but then there are exceptions, you know? Like, the Asbury Park community picnic in 1970 actually saw a tiny gain. So it's not totally consistent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Um, but then there are exceptions, you know? Like, the Asbury Park community picnic in nineteen seventy actually saw a tiny gain. So it's not totally consistent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1970, the year of the Asbury Park race riots, the index lost less than 1%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: True, but the pattern is strong enough to make you wonder. Even after major positive events—end of the Iraq War, celebrations post-Katrina—the market often tumbles.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but the pattern is strong enough to make you wonder. Even after major positive events-end of the Iraq War, celebrations post-Katrina-the market often tumbles.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2003, after protests erupted around the world over the Iraq War, the S&P jumped an eye watering 26%. In 2005, after civil unrest in New Orleans following Hurricane Katrina, the S&P gained 3%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And investors are apparently embracing what they call the three P's: peace, prosperity, positivity. But the market's still reacting negatively to social harmony.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And investors are apparently embracing what they call the three P's: peace, prosperity, positivity. But the market's still reacting negatively to social harmony.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors are continuing to ignore the three Pspandemic, protests and politicsand are instead focused on what increasingly is being interpreted as a quicker and better than expected recovery in the economy, David Donabedian, chief investment officer at CIBC Private Wealth Management, told the Wall Street Journal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Jim Cramer said it best—he thinks the market has a conscience. Like, investors are trying to do the right thing, even if it means short-term losses.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Jim Cramer said it best-he thinks the market has a conscience. Like, investors are trying to do the right thing, even if it means short-term losses.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the end of the day, the market has no conscience. Investors are simply trying to make money, CNBCs Jim Cramer said this week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then there's this optimism about future growth, right? The Fed's report says businesses are weirdly hopeful about the economic decline pace. It's confusing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then there's this optimism about future growth, right? The Fed's report says businesses are weirdly hopeful about the economic decline pace. It's confusing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserves most recent report about the state of the economy, for instance, indicated that even though all 50 states are beginning to take their first steps toward reopening, most businesses are still pessimistic about the pace of economic recovery.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And the IMF predicts banks will see profit gains through 2025, no cleanup needed for pandemic-era excess. So why the pessimism now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And the I M F predicts banks will see profit gains through twenty twenty five, no cleanup needed for pandemic-era excess. So why the pessimism now?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And last month, the IMF predicted that banks will suffer sharp declines in profits through 2025, and that substantial action will be needed to make up for earnings shortfalls caused by the coronavirus crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I guess because markets price in contraction before the data shows it. Todd Lowenstein mentioned that—the market lags behind actual events.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I guess because markets price in contraction before the data shows it. Todd Lowenstein mentioned that-the market lags behind actual events.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Markets will price in a recovery well before the economic data bottoms, says Todd Lowenstein, chief equity strategist at HighMark Capital Management. The market tends to be ahead of the actual data itself.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So even if things look bad now, the real bottom might not be here yet. It's like we're in this weird anticipatory phase.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So even if things look bad now, the real bottom might not be here yet. It's like we're in this weird anticipatory phase.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That means that the worst could be yet to come, even though the S&P seems poised to soar.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which makes investing feel like gambling on social mood rather than fundamentals. Unsettling, but fascinating.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which makes investing feel like gambling on social mood rather than fundamentals. Unsettling, but fascinating.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Let's see how this plays out with unemployment rates and Fed moves. Could be a wild ride.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Let's see how this plays out with unemployment rates and Fed moves. Could be a wild ride.

HostB: Um, but then there are exceptions, you know? Like, the Asbury Park community picnic in 1970 actually saw a tiny gain. So it’s not totally consistent.
HostA: True, but the pattern is strong enough to make you wonder. Even after major positive events—end of the Iraq War, celebrations post-Katrina—the market often tumbles.
HostB: And investors are apparently embracing what they call the three P's: peace, prosperity, positivity. But the market’s still reacting negatively to social harmony.
HostA: Jim Cramer said it best—he thinks the market has a conscience. Like, investors are trying to do the right thing, even if it means short-term losses.
HostB: But then there’s this optimism about future growth, right? The Fed’s report says businesses are weirdly hopeful about the economic decline pace. It’s confusing.
HostA: Exactly. And the IMF predicts banks will see profit gains through 2025, no cleanup needed for pandemic-era excess. So why the pessimism now?
HostB: I guess because markets price in contraction before the data shows it. Todd Lowenstein mentioned that—the market lags behind actual events.
HostA: So even if things look bad now, the real bottom might not be here yet. It’s like we’re in this weird anticipatory phase.
HostB: Which makes investing feel like gambling on social mood rather than fundamentals. Unsettling, but fascinating.
